mcc:description.gco:CharacterString: WGS_1984_Web_Mercator_Auxiliary_Sphere for interactive map optimization. Associated downloadable files are in Albers coordinate system.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Sagebrush Biome Conservation Anchors (Fig. 6) - Biome-wide sagebrush core habitat and growth areas estimated from a threat-based conservation design

cit:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Additional information about Originators: Doherty, Kevin E, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3635-7346; Theobald, David M, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1271-9368; Holdrege, Martin C, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4078-6012; Wiechman, Lief Andrew, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3804-4426; Bradford, John B, https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9257-6303

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: Link to the resource described in this citation

mri:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
File-based data for download: [https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/6328f759d34e71c6d67b7a40](http://)
Related report with figures: [https://doi.org/10.3133/ofr20221081](http://)
Identifying anchor points (that is, areas of spatial congruence) between core sagebrush areas (CSAs) and growth opportunity areas (GOAs) and existing (as of 2020) agency prioritizations within the sagebrush biome. Locations where core sagebrush areas and growth opportunity areas co-occur were mapped with at least one of the following designations: (a) Centrocercus urophasianus L. (greater sage-grouse) Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs), as used by State agencies and the National Resources Conservation Service; (b) Priority Habitat Management Areas (PHMAs), as used by the Bureau of Land Management and the U.S. Forest Service; and (c) Sagebrush Strategic Habitat Conservation (SHC) 50% Wildlife Population Cores for sagebrush obligate birds—greater sage-grouse, Spizella breweri (Cassin, 1856) (Brewer’s sparrow), Artemisiospiza nevadensis (Ridgway, 1874) sagebrush sparrow), and Oreoscoptes montanus (J.K. Townsend, 1837) (sage thrasher)—as used by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Additionally, the location of the areas with spatial congruence between plans which also had no to low threats for invasive annual grasses, human modification, and conifer woodlands expansion were identified. These areas represent anchor points for conservation delivery actions. Fed, Federal

mri:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Identify anchor points (that is, areas of spatial congruence) between core sagebrush areas (CSAs) and growth opportunity areas (GOAs) and existing (as of 2020) agency prioritizations within the sagebrush biome.

mri:credit.gco:CharacterString: We appreciate the in-kind staff time and expertise that the 12 Agency and Organizations of the authors contributed to this effort. This work would have not been possible without the diversity of disciplines and Agency/Org perspectives represented in this work. Funding to support this work came from the USFWS Science Application Program in legacy Region 6.

mco:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: United States Fish and Wildlife Service (Service) shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. While the Service makes every reasonable effort to ensure the accuracy and completeness of data provided for distribution, it may not have the necessary accuracy or completeness required for every possible intended use. The Service recommends that data users consult the associated metadata record to understand the quality and possible limitations of the data. The Service creates metadata records in accordance with the standards endorsed by the Federal Geographic Data Committee. As a result of the above considerations, the Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of the data. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data in a manner consistent with the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the Service, no warranty, expressed or implied, is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This applies to the use of the data both alone and in aggregate with other data and information.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: A Sagebrush Conservation Design to Proactively Restore America’s Sagebrush Biome

mri:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Anchor areas were defined and mapped as landscapes where CSAs and GOAs overlapped with one or more agency management designations and had no to low threats for all three of the modeled threats. These anchor landscapes represent places that are prioritized in multiple planning efforts and align with the “defend the core” strategy.

gmx:name.gco:CharacterString: Agency Anchors (2 of 2): Biome-wide sagebrush core habitat and growth areas estimated from a threat-based conservation design

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Identifying anchor points (that is, areas of spatial congruence) between core sagebrush areas (CSAs) and growth opportunity areas (GOAs) and existing (as of 2020) agency prioritizations within the sagebrush biome. Locations where core sagebrush areas and growth opportunity areas co-occur were mapped with at least one of the following designations: (a) Centrocercus urophasianus L. (greater sage-grouse) Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs), as used by State agencies and the National Resources Conservation Service; (b) Priority Habitat Management Areas (PHMAs), as used by the Bureau of Land Management and the U.S. Forest Service; and (c) Sagebrush Strategic Habitat Conservation (SHC) 50% Wildlife Population Cores for sagebrush obligate birds—greater sage-grouse, Spizella breweri (Cassin, 1856) (Brewer’s sparrow), Artemisiospiza nevadensis (Ridgway, 1874) sagebrush sparrow), and Oreoscoptes montanus (J.K. Townsend, 1837) (sage thrasher)—as used by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Additionally, the location of the areas with spatial congruence between plans which also had no to low threats for invasive annual grasses, human modification, and conifer woodlands expansion were identified. These areas represent anchor points for conservation delivery actions. Fed, Federal

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Biome-wide sagebrush core habitat and growth areas estimated from a threat-based conservation design

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Biome-wide sagebrush core habitat and growth areas estimated from a threat-based conservation design

mrl:description.gco:CharacterString: Anchor areas were defined and mapped as landscapes where CSAs and GOAs overlapped with one or more agency management designations and had no to low threats for all three of the modeled threats. These anchor landscapes represent places that are prioritized in multiple planning efforts and align with the “defend the core” strategy.

Data Quality Assessment and Quality Control (QAQC): We evaluated the resulting data using visual inspection of resulting maps. This was conducted by both the data analysts and the larger team of authors from the Larger Work Citation (Doherty et al 2022). Many authors have intimate familiarity with specific landscapes within the sagebrush biome, and they zoomed in on their areas to confirm that the results are realistic depictions of habitat quality and spatial distribution. We also examined the numeric distribution and range of resulting values to confirm the absence of extreme outliers that would indicate a potential error. We also compared our results to independent wildlife population studies to ensure that the inferences about habitat quality emerging from our analysis and consistent with other data about wildlife population geographic patterns and temporal trends (See ‘Larger Work Citation’, Doherty et al 2022). These checks were conducted in 2021 and 2022.
